awd_titl_txt: The Role of Visual Representations in Children's Learning about Biological Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological variation is among the most important ideas in modern science. Variability among members of a species provides the foundation for theories of genetics, natural selection, and evolution. However, people typically underestimate the amount of variability that occurs within a species over the life span of animals and from one generation to the next. Children especially seem to have cognitive biases that members of a species are largely identical. To improve children's learning about biology, educators need better ways to scaffold children's understanding of biological variability. Diagrams and other visual representations are useful in promoting learning about biological variability, but diagrams can also be confusing. This project focuses on designing better visual representations of important types of variability, such as variability across life stages (e.g., in metamorphosis) and variability between parent and offspring (in genetic transmission). By studying how to make more effective visual representations, this project will inform efforts to improve science education, and will also provide information about the ways in which children's cognitive biases influence their scientific thinking more generally. This project is supported by an award to the University of Wisconsin by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning. 

To investigate how visual representations can be used to promote learning and transfer about biological variability, researchers in cognitive development and education will focus on two types of visual representations: life cycle diagrams and genetic diagrams. The research will investigate three key issues. First, 6- to 12-year-old children's beliefs about inheritance will be investigated to examine how strongly they expect consistency of traits from parent to offspring (i.e., in genetic transmission). Second, a series of studies will investigate how features of diagrams affect children's learning and transfer of knowledge about the life cycle and about genetic transmission. The studies will address whether highlighting generality, avoiding extraneous details, and highlighting variability in diagrams lead to optimal learning and transfer. To investigate these issues, lab-based experiments will be carried out that compare children's learning from visual representations that vary in targeted ways. The data analysis will address how children transfer their knowledge beyond the exemplars that are the focus of the learning tasks. Third, the results of Studies 1 and 2 will be used to inform the design of optimized diagrams, and the effects of these optimized diagrams on learning about biological change will be investigated during science workshops at a children's museum and during community-based science events using a pre-test - intervention - post-test design. This aspect of the research will also examine whether effective learning activities about within-species variability support children's reasoning about natural selection, evolution, and inheritance. The potential for broader impacts is substantial. Enabling children (and adults) to recognize different types of variability could have a significant impact on their biological thought and on the design of biology instruction. Better understanding of how specific visual features of diagrams contribute to or detract from science understanding may have important implications for the design and use of visual representations to convey scientific information in both formal and informal learning environments. This project also supports collaboration between science educators and researchers in cognitive development, providing training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. Results will be shared with academic researchers, and with educators in formal and informal science learning environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biological variation is a foundational science concept. Within-species variation provides the basis for natural selection, evolution, and genetics. In this project, we investigated whether learning about biological variation can be supported with visual representations. We focused on the role of diagrams in students' learning about variation over the life cycle and through genetic inheritance.  

This project addressed three primary questions. 

  1. How do the diagrams used in lessons about biological variability influence students' learning? We focused on learning with realistic, perceptually rich diagrams and schematic, perceptually bland diagrams.

  2. How do visual representations affect learning in informal learning settings, such as game play? Do different types of diagrams lead to differences in players’ interactions during play?  

  3. How strongly do children expect consistency in genetic transmission from parents to offspring? For example, do children expect that brown-eyed parents will always have brown-eyed offspring?

We first investigated whether the diagrams used in lessons about the life cycle of insects influenced students' learning and generalization. In one study, we compared a lesson with perceptually rich, realistic images of insects and a lesson with perceptually bland, schematic images. Younger children (grades 1–2) learned more from the lesson with rich, realistic images. Older children (grades 4–5) generalized more after the lesson with perceptually bland, schematic images, but they often made incorrect generalizations (i.e., attributing metamorphosis to animals that do not experience it). These findings differ from previous findings with adults, for whom bland images supported more correct generalizations. In another study, we investigated the effects of perceptual richness in the backgrounds of life cycle diagrams. Children in grades 1–5 learned similar amounts from lessons with rich and plain backgrounds. However, younger children generalized less after a lesson with a rich background, suggesting it was distracting. 

We also compared the effects of lessons with perceptually rich and bland diagrams on learning about genetic inheritance. Adults showed no differences in learning from the two lessons, but children who received the lesson with rich diagrams learned more about inheritance than those who received the lesson with bland diagrams. In another set of studies, we compared perceptually rich diagrams and abstract diagrams, which used different-colored circles and squares to represent individuals with different traits. Adults and older children who received the lesson with abstract diagrams learned more than those who received the lesson with perceptually rich diagrams. After the lesson, they were more likely to believe that offspring that looked different from the parents were possible. 

Taken together, these findings suggest that the effects of perceptual richness of diagrams on learning shift over development. Realistic diagrams are attention-getting and can support learning, especially for children. However, extraneous details can be detrimental. Abstract diagrams can also support learning, especially for older children and adults.

We also developed a card game about the life cycle for children and caregivers, and we examined learning in the informal context of game play. We varied whether the game materials used perceptually rich or bland diagrams, and we found no differences in children's or caregivers' learning with the two sets of game materials. We are currently examining caregiver-child interactions during game play to understand the effects of the diagrams on the content of these interactions.

We also investigated whether learners expect consistency in genetic transmission. We conducted several studies investigating beliefs about transmission of eye color. These studies used two primary tasks. In the judgment task, participants saw images of animal parents that had the same or different eye colors. They then saw several possible offspring that varied in eye color and judged whether each could be the offspring of those parents. Possible offspring had eye colors that were identical to the parents, blended the parents' eye colors, or differed from the parents. In the prediction task, participants predicted how 6 offspring of the animal parents would look, using the same set of possible offspring. In both tasks, children and adults judged that multiple offspring types were possible--not only ones that resembled the parents--and they judged more types as possible when the parents had different eye colors. Many children and adults also believed that female offspring would look like their mothers and male offspring would look like their fathers--a bias we termed the “sex-matching bias”.

The project has resulted in 5 peer-reviewed published articles, one article under review, and multiple conference presentations.

The project findings suggest ways to improve how information is presented visually in both formal and informal science education settings. The project has also yielded new knowledge about children's and adults' understanding of foundational biological concepts, including the life cycle, metamorphosis, and genetic inheritance. The research has involved developing and field-testing games about foundational biology concepts for use in museums and classrooms. The findings are relevant for teachers, curriculum designers, museum staff, and scientists who communicate about biological variability.
